citation: Banerjee, A., et al. (2015). A multifaceted program causes lasting progress for the very poor: Evidence from six countries. Science.
intervention: Productive inclusion ('Graduation') package: asset transfer + training + consumption support
finding_summary: The graduation program caused broad and lasting improvements in consumption, asset holdings, and income in 5 out of 6 countries.
geography: Ethiopia, Ghana, Honduras, India, Pakistan, Peru

citation: Muralidharan, K., Singh, A., & Ganimian, A. J. (2017). Disrupting Education? Experimental Evidence on Technology-Aided Instruction in India. NBER.
finding_summary: The program increased math scores by 0.37 SD and Hindi scores by 0.23 SD in just 4.5 months. It was cost-effective and closed the learning gap.

citation: Baird, S., McIntosh, C., & Ozler, B. (2011). Cash or Condition? Evidence from a Cash Transfer Experiment. QJE.
intervention: Conditional Cash Transfers (CCT) vs Unconditional Cash Transfers (UCT)
finding_summary: CCTs were significantly more effective than UCTs at keeping adolescent girls in school, but UCTs were more effective at delaying marriage and pregnancy.

citation: Duflo, E. (2001). Schooling and Labor Market Consequences of School Construction in Indonesia. AER.
finding_summary: Construction of schools led to an increase in years of education (0.12 to 0.19 years) and an increase in future wages (1.5% to 2.7%) for each school built per 1,000 children.

citation: Haushofer, J., & Shapiro, J. (2016). The Short-term Impact of Unconditional Cash Transfers to the Poor: Evidence from Kenya. QJE.
finding_summary: Transfers increased monthly consumption by $36 (PPP) and assets by $302. Significant improvements in psychological well-being (happiness, life satisfaction) were observed.
